location: The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.

lines.text: Enter THERSITES, solus

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: How now, Thersites! what lost in the labyrinth of thy fury! Shall the elephant Ajax carry it thus? He beats me, and I rail at him: O, worthy satisfaction! would it were otherwise; that I could beat him, whilst he railed at me. 'Sfoot, I'll learn to conjure and raise devils, but I'll see some issue of my spiteful execrations. Then there's Achilles, a rare enginer! If Troy be not taken till these two undermine it, the walls will stand till they fall of themselves. O thou great thunder-darter of Olympus, forget that thou art Jove, the king of gods and, Mercury, lose all the serpentine craft of thy caduceus, if ye take not that little, little less than little wit from them that they have! which short-armed ignorance itself knows is so abundant scarce, it will not in circumvention deliver a fly from a spider, without drawing their massy irons and cutting the web. After this, the vengeance on the whole camp! or rather, the bone-ache! for that, methinks, is the curse dependent on those that war for a placket. I have said my prayers and devil Envy say Amen. What ho! my Lord Achilles!
Enter PATROCLUS

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: Who's there? Thersites! Good Thersites, come in and rail.

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: If I could have remembered a gilt counterfeit, thou wouldst not have slipped out of my contemplation: but it is no matter; thyself upon thyself! The common curse of mankind, folly and ignorance, be thine in great revenue! heaven bless thee from a tutor, and discipline come not near thee! Let thy blood be thy direction till thy death! then if she that lays thee out says thou art a fair corse, I'll be sworn and sworn upon't she never shrouded any but lazars. Amen. Where's Achilles?

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: What, art thou devout? wast thou in prayer?

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: Ay: the heavens hear me!
Enter ACHILLES

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: Who's there?

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: Thersites, my lord.

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: Where, where? Art thou come? why, my cheese, my digestion, why hast thou not served thyself in to my table so many meals? Come, what's Agamemnon?

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: Thy commander, Achilles. Then tell me, Patroclus, what's Achilles?

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: Thy lord, Thersites: then tell me, I pray thee, what's thyself?

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: Thy knower, Patroclus: then tell me, Patroclus, what art thou?

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: Thou mayst tell that knowest.

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: O, tell, tell.

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: I'll decline the whole question. Agamemnon commands Achilles; Achilles is my lord; I am Patroclus' knower, and Patroclus is a fool.

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: You rascal!

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: Peace, fool! I have not done.

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: He is a privileged man. Proceed, Thersites.

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: Agamemnon is a fool; Achilles is a fool; Thersites is a fool, and, as aforesaid, Patroclus is a fool.

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: Derive this; come.

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: Agamemnon is a fool to offer to command Achilles; Achilles is a fool to be commanded of Agamemnon; Thersites is a fool to serve such a fool, and Patroclus is a fool positive.

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: Why am I a fool?

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: Make that demand of the prover. It suffices me thou art. Look you, who comes here?

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: Patroclus, I'll speak with nobody. Come in with me, Thersites.
Exit

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: Here is such patchery, such juggling and such knavery! all the argument is a cuckold and a whore; a good quarrel to draw emulous factions and bleed to death upon. Now, the dry serpigo on the subject! and war and lechery confound all!
Exit
Enter AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, NESTOR, DIOMEDES, and AJAX

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: Where is Achilles?

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: Within his tent; but ill disposed, my lord.

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: Let it be known to him that we are here. He shent our messengers; and we lay by Our appertainments, visiting of him: Let him be told so; lest perchance he think We dare not move the question of our place, Or know not what we are.

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: I shall say so to him.
Exit

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: We saw him at the opening of his tent: He is not sick.

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: Yes, lion-sick, sick of proud heart: you may call it melancholy, if you will favour the man; but, by my head, 'tis pride: but why, why? let him show us the cause. A word, my lord.
Takes AGAMEMNON aside

lines.speaker: nestor
lines.text: What moves Ajax thus to bay at him?

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: Achilles hath inveigled his fool from him.

lines.speaker: nestor
lines.text: Who, Thersites?

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: He.

lines.speaker: nestor
lines.text: Then will Ajax lack matter, if he have lost his argument.

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: No, you see, he is his argument that has his argument, Achilles.

lines.speaker: nestor
lines.text: All the better; their fraction is more our wish than their faction: but it was a strong composure a fool could disunite.

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: The amity that wisdom knits not, folly may easily untie. Here comes Patroclus.
Re-enter PATROCLUS

lines.speaker: nestor
lines.text: No Achilles with him.

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: The elephant hath joints, but none for courtesy: his legs are legs for necessity, not for flexure.

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: Achilles bids me say, he is much sorry, If any thing more than your sport and pleasure Did move your greatness and this noble state To call upon him; he hopes it is no other But for your health and your digestion sake, And after-dinner's breath.

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: Hear you, Patroclus: We are too well acquainted with these answers: But his evasion, wing'd thus swift with scorn, Cannot outfly our apprehensions. Much attribute he hath, and much the reason Why we ascribe it to him; yet all his virtues, Not virtuously on his own part beheld, Do in our eyes begin to lose their gloss, Yea, like fair fruit in an unwholesome dish, Are like to rot untasted. Go and tell him, We come to speak with him; and you shall not sin, If you do say we think him over-proud And under-honest, in self-assumption greater Than in the note of judgment; and worthier than himself Here tend the savage strangeness he puts on, Disguise the holy strength of their command, And underwrite in an observing kind His humorous predominance; yea, watch His pettish lunes, his ebbs, his flows, as if The passage and whole carriage of this action Rode on his tide. Go tell him this, and add, That if he overhold his price so much, We'll none of him; but let him, like an engine Not portable, lie under this report: 'Bring action hither, this cannot go to war: A stirring dwarf we do allowance give Before a sleeping giant.' Tell him so.

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: I shall; and bring his answer presently.
Exit

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: In second voice we'll not be satisfied; We come to speak with him. Ulysses, enter you.
Exit ULYSSES

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: What is he more than another?

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: No more than what he thinks he is.

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: Is he so much? Do you not think he thinks himself a better man than I am?

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: No question.

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: Will you subscribe his thought, and say he is?

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: No, noble Ajax; you are as strong, as valiant, as wise, no less noble, much more gentle, and altogether more tractable.

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: Why should a man be proud? How doth pride grow? I know not what pride is.

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: Your mind is the clearer, Ajax, and your virtues the fairer. He that is proud eats up himself: pride is his own glass, his own trumpet, his own chronicle; and whatever praises itself but in the deed, devours the deed in the praise.

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: I do hate a proud man, as I hate the engendering of toads.

lines.speaker: nestor
lines.text: Yet he loves himself: is't not strange?
Aside
Re-enter ULYSSES

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: Achilles will not to the field to-morrow.

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: What's his excuse?

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: He doth rely on none, But carries on the stream of his dispose Without observance or respect of any, In will peculiar and in self-admission.

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: Why will he not upon our fair request Untent his person and share the air with us?

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: Things small as nothing, for request's sake only, He makes important: possess'd he is with greatness, And speaks not to himself but with a pride That quarrels at self-breath: imagined worth Holds in his blood such swoln and hot discourse That 'twixt his mental and his active parts Kingdom'd Achilles in commotion rages And batters down himself: what should I say? He is so plaguy proud that the death-tokens of it Cry 'No recovery.'

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: Let Ajax go to him. Dear lord, go you and greet him in his tent: 'Tis said he holds you well, and will be led At your request a little from himself.

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: O Agamemnon, let it not be so! We'll consecrate the steps that Ajax makes When they go from Achilles: shall the proud lord That bastes his arrogance with his own seam And never suffers matter of the world Enter his thoughts, save such as do revolve And ruminate himself, shall he be worshipp'd Of that we hold an idol more than he? No, this thrice worthy and right valiant lord Must not so stale his palm, nobly acquired; Nor, by my will, assubjugate his merit, As amply titled as Achilles is, By going to Achilles: That were to enlard his fat already pride And add more coals to Cancer when he burns With entertaining great Hyperion. This lord go to him! Jupiter forbid, And say in thunder 'Achilles go to him.'

lines.speaker: nestor
lines.text: [Aside to DIOMEDES]  O, this is well; he rubs the vein of him.

lines.speaker: diomedes
lines.text: [Aside to NESTOR]  And how his silence drinks up this applause!

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: If I go to him, with my armed fist I'll pash him o'er the face.

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: O, no, you shall not go.

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: An a' be proud with me, I'll pheeze his pride: Let me go to him.

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: Not for the worth that hangs upon our quarrel.

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: A paltry, insolent fellow!

lines.speaker: nestor
lines.text: How he describes himself!

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: Can he not be sociable?

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: The raven chides blackness.

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: I'll let his humours blood.

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: He will be the physician that should be the patient.

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: An all men were o' my mind,--

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: Wit would be out of fashion.

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: A' should not bear it so, a' should eat swords first: shall pride carry it?

lines.speaker: nestor
lines.text: An 'twould, you'ld carry half.

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: A' would have ten shares.

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: I will knead him; I'll make him supple.

lines.speaker: nestor
lines.text: He's not yet through warm: force him with praises: pour in, pour in; his ambition is dry.

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: [To AGAMEMNON]  My lord, you feed too much on this dislike.

lines.speaker: nestor
lines.text: Our noble general, do not do so.

lines.speaker: diomedes
lines.text: You must prepare to fight without Achilles.

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: Why, 'tis this naming of him does him harm. Here is a man--but 'tis before his face; I will be silent.

lines.speaker: nestor
lines.text: Wherefore should you so? He is not emulous, as Achilles is.

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: Know the whole world, he is as valiant.

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: A whoreson dog, that shall pelter thus with us! Would he were a Trojan!

lines.speaker: nestor
lines.text: What a vice were it in Ajax now,--

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: If he were proud,--

lines.speaker: diomedes
lines.text: Or covetous of praise,--

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: Ay, or surly borne,--

lines.speaker: diomedes
lines.text: Or strange, or self-affected!

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: Thank the heavens, lord, thou art of sweet composure; Praise him that got thee, she that gave thee suck: Famed be thy tutor, and thy parts of nature Thrice famed, beyond all erudition: But he that disciplined thy arms to fight, Let Mars divide eternity in twain, And give him half: and, for thy vigour, Bull-bearing Milo his addition yield To sinewy Ajax. I will not praise thy wisdom, Which, like a bourn, a pale, a shore, confines Thy spacious and dilated parts: here's Nestor; Instructed by the antiquary times, He must, he is, he cannot but be wise: Put pardon, father Nestor, were your days As green as Ajax' and your brain so temper'd, You should not have the eminence of him, But be as Ajax.

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: Shall I call you father?

lines.speaker: nestor
lines.text: Ay, my good son.

lines.speaker: diomedes
lines.text: Be ruled by him, Lord Ajax.

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: There is no tarrying here; the hart Achilles Keeps thicket. Please it our great general To call together all his state of war; Fresh kings are come to Troy: to-morrow We must with all our main of power stand fast: And here's a lord,--come knights from east to west, And cull their flower, Ajax shall cope the best.

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: Go we to council. Let Achilles sleep: Light boats sail swift, though greater hulks draw deep.
Exeunt
